RHUL CS seminars -- Autumn 23/24

Welcome to the RHUL CS seminars webpage. Our seminars run on Wednesdays 15:00 - 16:00 during term time.

Click on Show Details to see the venue, link to live-streaming, the abstract, and a link to the recording after the seminar.

Time Speaker Title
30 Nov 2022, 15:00 () Show Details

Venue

Shilling 0-04 [MS Teams Link]

Abstract

In the area of data analysis and arguably even in machine learning as a whole, few approaches have been as impactful as the classical k-means clustering. Here, we study the complexity of k-means clustering in settings where most of the data is not known. To obtain a more detailed understanding of the theoretic tractability of this clustering problem, we apply the parameterised complexity paradigm and obtain new algorithms for k-means clustering of incomplete data: one for the clustering of bounded-domain (i.e., integer) data, and two algorithms that target real-valued data. Our approach is based on exploiting structural properties of a graphical encoding of the missing data, and we show that tractability can be achieved using significantly less restrictive parameterisations than in the complementary case of few missing entries.

30 Nov 2022, 15:00 Thekla Hamm (Technical University of Vienna) The Complexity of k-Means Clustering when Little is Known Complexity Technical Show Details

Venue

Shilling 0-04 [MS Teams Link]

Abstract

In the area of data analysis and arguably even in machine learning as a whole, few approaches have been as impactful as the classical k-means clustering. Here, we study the complexity of k-means clustering in settings where most of the data is not known. To obtain a more detailed understanding of the theoretic tractability of this clustering problem, we apply the parameterised complexity paradigm and obtain new algorithms for k-means clustering of incomplete data: one for the clustering of bounded-domain (i.e., integer) data, and two algorithms that target real-valued data. Our approach is based on exploiting structural properties of a graphical encoding of the missing data, and we show that tractability can be achieved using significantly less restrictive parameterisations than in the complementary case of few missing entries.
